title: L'Orfeo
factoid: Widely regarded as the first operatic masterwork.

title: Il ritorno d'Ulisse in patria
factoid: Monteverdi's first opera for Venice, based on Homer's Odyssey, displays the composer's mastery of portrayal of genuine individuals as opposed to stereotypes.

title: L'incoronazione di Poppea
factoid: Monteverdi's last opera, composed for a Venetian audience, is often performed today. Its Venetian context helps to explain the complete absence of the moralizing tone often associated with opera of this time.

title: Ormindo
factoid: One of the first of Cavalli's operas to be revived in the 20th century, Ormindo is considered one of his more attractive works.

title: Giasone
factoid: In Giasone Cavalli, for the first time, separated aria and recitative. Giasone was the most popular opera of the 17th century.

title: La Calisto
factoid: Ninth of the eleven operas that Cavalli wrote with Faustini is noted for its satire of the deities of classical mythology.

title: Dido and Aeneas
factoid: Often considered to be the first genuine English-language operatic masterwork. Not first performed in 1689 at a girls' school, as is commonly believed, but at Charles II's court in 1683.

title: The Fairy-Queen
factoid: A semi-opera rather than a genuine opera, this is often thought to be Purcell's finest dramatic work.

title: Agrippina
factoid: Handel's last opera that he composed in Italy was a great success, and established his reputation as a composer of Italian opera.

title: Rinaldo
factoid: Handel's first opera for the London stage was also the first all-Italian opera performed on the London stage.

title: Giulio Cesare
factoid: Noted for the richness of its orchestration.

title: Tamerlano
factoid: Described by Anthony Hicks, writing in Grove Music Online, as possessing a "taut dramatic power".

title: Rodelinda
factoid: Rodelinda is often praised[by whom?] for the fullness of the melodic writing among Handel's output.

title: The Beggar's Opera
factoid: A satire of Italian opera seria based on a play by John Gay, the ballad opera format of The Beggar's Opera has proved popular even up to the current time.

title: Acis and Galatea
factoid: Handel's only work for the theatre that is set to an English libretto.

title: Orlando
factoid: An opera that is described by Anthony Hicks as "remarkable" and by Orrey as one of Handel's "best works".

title: La serva padrona
factoid: Became a model for many of the opera buffas that followed it, including those of Mozart.

title: Hippolyte et Aricie
factoid: Rameau's first opera caused great controversy at its premiere.

title: Ariodante
factoid: Both this opera and Alcina enjoy high critical reputations today.

title: Alcina
factoid: Both this work and Ariodante were part of Handel's first opera season at Covent Garden.

title: Les Indes galantes
factoid: In this work Rameau added emotional depth and power to the traditionally lighter form of opéra-ballet.

title: Castor et Pollux
factoid: Initially only a moderate success, when it was revived in 1754 Castor et Pollux was regarded as Rameau's finest achievement.

title: Serse
factoid: Deviation from the usual model of opera seria, Serse contains many comic elements rare in Handel's other works.

title: Semele
factoid: Originally performed as an oratorio, Semele's dramatic qualities have often led to the work being performed on the opera stage in modern times.

title: Platée
factoid: Rameau's most famous comic opera. Originally a court entertainment, a 1754 revival proved extremely popular with French audiences.

title: La buona figliuola
factoid: Piccinni's work was initially immensely popular throughout Europe. By 1790 over 70 productions of the opera had been produced and it had been performed in all the major European cities.

title: Orfeo ed Euridice
factoid: Gluck's most popular opera. The first work in which the composer tried to reform the excesses of Italian opera seria.

title: Artaxerxes
factoid: The first opera seria in English. After Metastasio's 1729 libretto Artaserse.

title: Alceste
factoid: Gluck's second "reform" opera, nowadays usually given in its French revision of 1776.

title: Bastien und Bastienne
factoid: Mozart's one-act Singspiel was set to a parody of Rousseau's Le devin du village.

title: Mitridate, re di Ponto
factoid: Composed when Mozart was 14, Mitridate was written for a demanding cast of star singers.

title: Lucio Silla
factoid: from Mozart's teenage years, was not revived until 1929 after its initial run of 25 performances.

title: Iphigénie en Aulide
factoid: Gluck's first opera for Paris.

title: La finta giardiniera
factoid: Generally recognised as Mozart's first opera buffa of significance.

title: Il re pastore
factoid: Mozart's last opera of his adolescence was set to a libretto by Metastasio.

title: Il mondo della luna
factoid: Last of three that Haydn set to libretti by Carlo Goldoni.

title: Armide
factoid: Gluck used a libretto originally set by Lully for this French work, his favourite among his own operas.

title: Iphigénie en Tauride
factoid: Gluck's "last and perhaps greatest masterpiece".

title: Idomeneo
factoid: Usually thought of as Mozart's first mature opera, Idomeneo was composed after a lengthy break from the stage.

title: Die Entführung aus dem Serail
factoid: Often thought of as the first of Mozart's comic masterpieces, this work is frequently performed today.

title: Il barbiere di Siviglia
factoid: Paisiello's most famous comic opera, later eclipsed by Rossini's work of the same name.

title: Der Schauspieldirektor
factoid: Another Singspiel with much spoken dialogue taken from plays of that time, the plot of Der Schauspieldirektor features two sopranos vying to become prima donna in a newly assembled company. Premiered together with Antonio Salieri's Prima la musica e poi le parole

title: Le nozze di Figaro
factoid: The first of the famous series of Mozart operas set to libretti by Lorenzo Da Ponte is now Mozart's most popular opera.

title: Don Giovanni
factoid: Second of the operas that Mozart set to Da Ponte's libretti, Don Giovanni has provided a puzzle for writers and philosophers ever since its composition.

title: Così fan tutte
factoid: Third and last of the operas that Mozart set to libretti by Da Ponte, Così fan tutte was scarcely performed throughout the 19th century, as the plot was considered to be immoral.

title: La clemenza di Tito
factoid: Mozart's last opera before his early death was extremely popular until 1830, after which the work's popularity and critical reputation began to decline; they did not return to their former levels until after the Second World War.

title: Die Zauberflöte
factoid: Has been described as "the apotheosis of the Singspiel", Die Zauberflöte was denigrated during the 19th century as confused and lacking in definition.

title: Il matrimonio segreto
factoid: Usually regarded as Cimarosa's best opera, Leopold II enjoyed the three-hour-long premiere so much that, after dinner, he compelled the singers to repeat the opera later during that same day.

title: Médée
factoid: Only French opera of the Revolutionary period to be regularly performed today. A famous showcase for sopranos such as Maria Callas.

title: Fidelio
factoid: Beethoven's only opera was inspired by the composer's passion for political liberty.

title: La vestale
factoid: Spontini's opera about a vestal virgin in love was a great influence on Berlioz and a forerunner of French grand opera.

title: La scala di seta
factoid: An early Rossini work, this opera is outright farsa comica.

title: L'italiana in Algeri
factoid: This opera is described by Richard Osborne, writing in Grove Music Online, as "Rossini's first buffo masterpiece in the fully fledged two-act form".

title: Tancredi
factoid: This melodramma eroico was described by poet Giuseppe Carpani thus: "It is cantilena and always cantilena: beautiful cantilena, new cantilena, magic cantilena, rare cantilena".

title: Il turco in Italia
factoid: This opera stands out among Rossini's output for its frequent ensembles and absence of aria.

title: Il barbiere di Siviglia
factoid: This work has become Rossini's most popular opera buffa.

title: Otello
factoid: The composer Giacomo Meyerbeer described the third act of Otello thus: "The third act of Otello established its reputation so firmly that a thousand errors could not shake it".

title: La Cenerentola
factoid: Rossini's comedy was composed in just over three weeks.

title: La gazza ladra
factoid: In this opera Rossini drew upon French rescue opera.

title: Mosè in Egitto
factoid: This work was originally conceived of as a sacred drama suitable for performance during Lent.

title: La donna del lago
factoid: Another Romantic-era opera inspired by the works of Sir Walter Scott.

title: Der Freischütz
factoid: Weber's masterpiece was the first great German Romantic opera.

title: Euryanthe
factoid: Despite its weak libretto, Euryanthe had a great influence on later German operas, including Wagner's Lohengrin.

title: Semiramide
factoid: This is the last opera that Rossini composed in Italy.

title: La dame blanche
factoid: Boieldieu's most successful opéra comique was one of many 19th century works inspired by the novels of Sir Walter Scott.

title: Le siège de Corinthe
factoid: For this work Rossini heavily revised his earlier Maometto II, placing the action in a different setting.

title: Oberon
factoid: Weber's last opera before his early death.

title: Il pirata
factoid: Bellini's second professional production established his international reputation.

title: Der Vampyr
factoid: Marschner was a key link between Weber and Wagner, as this Gothic opera shows.

title: Le comte Ory
factoid: Rossini's opera has enjoyed a high critical reputation throughout the years: 19th-century critic Henry Chorley said that "there is not a bad melody, there is not an ugly bar in Le comte Ory", and Richard Osborne, writing in Grove Music Online, calls details that the work is one of the "wittiest, most stylish and most urbane of all comic operas".

title: La straniera
factoid: La straniera is rare among bel canto operas in that it offers remarkably few opportunities for vocal ostentation.

title: Guillaume Tell
factoid: Rossini's last opera before his retirement is a tale of liberty set in the Swiss Alps. It helped to establish the genre of French Grand Opera.

title: Anna Bolena
factoid: This was Donizetti's first success on the international scene and helped greatly to establish his reputation.

title: Fra Diavolo
factoid: One of the most popular opéra comiques of the 19th century, Auber's tale loosely based on an important Neapolitan rebel leader even inspired a film by Laurel and Hardy.

title: I Capuleti e i Montecchi
factoid: Bellini's version of Romeo and Juliet.

title: La sonnambula
factoid: The concertato "D'un pensiero e d'un accento" from the finale of Act 1 of this work was later parodied by Arthur Sullivan in Trial by Jury.

title: Norma
factoid: Bellini's best-known opera, paradigm of Romantic operas. The final act of this work is often noted for the originality of its orchestration.

title: Robert le diable
factoid: Meyerbeer's first Grand Opera for Paris caused a sensation with its ballet of dead nuns.

title: L'elisir d'amore
factoid: This work was the most often performed opera in Italy between 1838 and 1848.

title: Beatrice di Tenda
factoid: Bellini's tragedy is notable for its extensive use of the chorus.

title: Hans Heiling
factoid: Another important Gothic horror opera from Marschner.

title: Lucrezia Borgia
factoid: One of Donizetti's most popular scores.

title: Maria Stuarda
factoid: This work was dismissed as a failure in the 19th century, but since its revival in 1958 it has made frequent appearances on stage.

title: Das Liebesverbot
factoid: An early work by Wagner loosely based on Shakespeare's Measure for Measure. The composer later disowned it.

title: I puritani
factoid: Bellini's drama, set during the English Civil War, is one of his finest achievements.

title: La Juive
factoid: This grand opera rivalled the works of Meyerbeer in popularity. The tenor aria "Rachel quand du seigneur" is particularly famous.

title: Lucia di Lammermoor
factoid: Donizetti's most famous tragic opera, notable for Lucia's mad scene.

title: A Life for the Tsar
factoid: Glinka established the tradition of Russian opera with this historical work and the later Ruslan and Lyudmila.

title: Les Huguenots
factoid: Perhaps the most famous of all French grand operas, widely regarded as Meyerbeer's masterpiece.

title: Roberto Devereux
factoid: Donizetti wrote this work as a distraction from the grief he felt at the death of his wife.

title: Benvenuto Cellini
factoid: Berlioz's first opera is a virtuoso score which is still highly difficult to perform.

title: Oberto, conte di San Bonifacio
factoid: Verdi's first opera is a sensational melodrama.

title: La favorite
factoid: A grand opera in the French tradition.

title: La fille du régiment
factoid: Donizetti's venture into French opéra comique.

title: Bátori Mária
factoid: Erkel's first opera was also the first true opera written in Hungarian and is based on the story of Ines de Castro in Camões' Os Lusiadas, the Portuguese national epic.

title: Un giorno di regno
factoid: Verdi's only comedy apart from his last opera, Falstaff.

title: Der Wildschütz
factoid: Lortzing's "comic masterpiece", intended to show a German work could rival Italian opera buffa and French opéra comique.

title: Nabucco
factoid: Verdi described this opera as the genuine beginning of his artistic career.

title: Rienzi
factoid: Wagner's contribution to the Grand Opera tradition.

title: Ruslan and Lyudmila
factoid: This episodic version of a Pushkin fairy tale was a major influence on later Russian composers.

title: Der fliegende Holländer
factoid: Wagner regarded this German Romantic opera as the true beginning of his career.

title: Don Pasquale
factoid: Donizetti's "comic masterpiece" is one of the last great opera buffas.

title: I Lombardi alla prima crociata
factoid: Verdi's follow-up to Nabucco was the first of his operas to be performed in America.

title: The Bohemian Girl
factoid: One of the few notable 19th-century English-language operas apart from the works of Gilbert and Sullivan.

title: Hunyadi László
factoid: Erkel's second opera is generally considered his best, but is second in popularity to his later opera Bánk Bán which is considered the Hungarian "National Opera".

title: Ernani
factoid: One of the most dramatically effective of Verdi's early works.

title: Tannhäuser und der Sängerkrieg auf Wartburg
factoid: Wagner's "most medieval work" depicts the conflict between pagan love and Christian virtue.

title: Attila
factoid: Verdi was troubled by ill health during the writing of this piece, which was only a moderate success at the premiere.

title: La damnation de Faust
factoid: Frustrated at his lack of opera commissions, Berlioz composed this "dramatic legend" for concert performance. In recent years, it has been successfully staged as an opera, though the critic David Cairns describes it as "cinematic".

title: Macbeth
factoid: Verdi's first venture into Shakespeare.

title: Martha
factoid: Flotow unashamedly aimed at satisfying popular taste in this comic and sentimental work set in the England of Queen Anne.

title: Die lustigen Weiber von Windsor
factoid: Nicolai's only German opera has been his most lasting success.

title: Le prophète
factoid: A grand opera about the life of the religious fanatic, John of Leiden.

title: Luisa Miller
factoid: Fans of Verdi think that this setting of Schiller's "bourgeois tragedy" has been underrated.

title: Genoveva
factoid: Schumann's only excursion into opera was a relative failure, though the work has had its admirers from Franz Liszt to Nikolaus Harnoncourt.

title: Lohengrin
factoid: The last of Wagner's "middle period" works.

title: Stiffelio
factoid: Verdi's tale of adultery among members of a German Protestant sect fell foul of the censors.

title: Rigoletto
factoid: The first – and most innovative – of three middle period Verdi operas which have become staples of the repertoire.

title: Il trovatore
factoid: This Romantic melodrama is one of Verdi's most tuneful scores.

title: La traviata
factoid: The role of Violetta, the "fallen woman" of the title, is one of the most famous vehicles for the soprano voice.

title: Les vêpres siciliennes
factoid: Verdi's opera displays the strong influence of Meyerbeer.

title: Der Barbier von Bagdad
factoid: An oriental comedy drawing on the tradition of German Romantic opera.

title: Orphée aux Enfers
factoid: Offenbach's first full-length operetta, this cynical and satirical piece is still immensely popular today.

title: Les Troyens
factoid: Berlioz's greatest opera and the culmination of the French Classical tradition.

title: Faust
factoid: Of all the musical settings of the Faust legend, Gounod's has been the most popular with audiences, especially in the Victorian era.

title: Un ballo in maschera
factoid: This opera ran into trouble with the censors because it originally dealt with the assassination of a monarch.

title: Bánk bán
factoid: Erkel's third opera is considered the Hungarian "National opera".

title: Béatrice et Bénédict
factoid: The last opera Berlioz wrote is the final fruit of his lifelong admiration for Shakespeare.

title: La forza del destino
factoid: This tragedy was commissioned by the Imperial Theatre, Saint Petersburg, and Verdi may have been influenced by the Russian tradition in the writing of his work.

title: Les pêcheurs de perles
factoid: Though a relative failure at its premiere, this is Bizet's second most performed opera today and is particularly famous for its tenor/baritone duet.

title: La belle Hélène
factoid: Another operetta by Offenbach which pokes fun at Greek mythology.

title: Mireille
factoid: Gounod's work is based on the epic poem by Frédéric Mistral and makes use of Provençal folk tunes.

title: L'Africaine
factoid: Meyerbeer's last Grand Opera received a posthumous premiere.

title: Tristan und Isolde
factoid: This romantic tragedy is Wagner's most radical work and one of the most revolutionary pieces in music history. The "Tristan chord" began the breakdown of traditional tonality.

title: Mignon
factoid: A lyrical work inspired by Goethe's novel Wilhelm Meister's Apprenticeship, this was Thomas's most successful opera along with Hamlet.

title: The Bartered Bride
factoid: Smetana's folk comedy is the most widely performed of all his operas.

title: Don Carlos
factoid: Verdi's French grand opera, after Schiller, is now one of his most highly regarded works.

title: La jolie fille de Perth
factoid: Bizet turned to a novel by Sir Walter Scott for this opéra comique.

title: Roméo et Juliette
factoid: Gounod's version of Shakespeare's tragedy is his second most famous work.

title: Dalibor
factoid: One of the most successful of Smetana's operas exploring themes from Czech history.

title: Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg
factoid: Wagner's only comedy among his mature operas concerns the clash between artistic tradition and innovation.

title: Hamlet
factoid: Thomas's opera takes many liberties with its Shakespearean source.

title: La Périchole
factoid: Set in Peru, this operetta mixes comedy and sentimentality.

title: Mefistofele
factoid: Though most famous as a librettist for Verdi, Boito was also a composer and he spent many years working on this musical version of the Faust myth.

title: Das Rheingold
factoid: The "preliminary evening" to Wagner's epic Ring cycle tells how the ring was forged and the curse laid upon it.

title: Die Walküre
factoid: The second part of the Ring tells the story of the mortals Siegmund and Sieglinde and of how the valkyrie Brünnhilde disobeys her father Wotan, king of the gods.

title: Aida
factoid: Features one of the greatest tenor arias of all time, Celeste Aida.

title: Boris Godunov
factoid: Mussorgsky's great historical drama shows Russia's descent into anarchy in the early 17th century.

title: Die Fledermaus
factoid: Probably the most popular of all operettas.

title: The Two Widows
factoid: Another comedy by Smetana, the only one of his operas with a non-Czech subject.

title: Carmen
factoid: Probably the most famous of all French operas. Critics at the premiere were shocked by Bizet's blend of romanticism and realism.

title: Siegfried
factoid: The third part of the Ring sees the hero Siegfried slay the dragon Fafner, win the ring and free Brunhilde from her enchantment.

title: Götterdämmerung
factoid: In the final part of the Ring, the curse takes effect leading to the deaths of Siegfried and Brünnhilde and the destruction of the gods themselves.

title: La Gioconda
factoid: Apart from Verdi's Aida, this is the only Italian grand opera to have stayed in international repertory.

title: L'étoile
factoid: This comic piece has been described as "a cross between Carmen and Gilbert and Sullivan, with plenty of Offenbach thrown in".

title: Samson et Dalila
factoid: An opera with that was heavily influenced by those of Wagner.

title: Eugene Onegin
factoid: Tchaikovsky's most popular opera, based on the verse novel by Alexander Pushkin. The composer strongly identified with the heroine Tatyana.

title: Hérodiade
factoid: An opera telling the Biblical story of Salome, Massenet's work was eclipsed by Richard Strauss's treatment of the same subject.

title: Les contes d'Hoffmann
factoid: Offenbach's attempt at writing a more serious work remained unfinished at his death. Nevertheless, this is his most widely performed opera today.

title: Simon Boccanegra
factoid: Verdi heavily revised this opera over twenty years after it was first performed.

title: Parsifal
factoid: Wagner's last opera is a "festival play" about the legend of the Holy Grail.

title: The Snow Maiden
factoid: One of Rimsky-Korsakov's most lyrical works.

title: Lakmé
factoid: This opéra comique set in the British Raj in India is famous for its "Flower Duet" and "Bell Song".

title: Le Villi
factoid: An early operatic work by Puccini with plenty of opportunity for dance.

title: Manon
factoid: Massenet's most enduringly popular work along with Werther.

title: Der Zigeunerbaron
factoid: Strauss's operetta was intended to soothe tensions between Austrians and Hungarians in the Habsburg empire.

title: Khovanshchina
factoid: Mussorgsky's second great epic of Russian history was left unfinished at his death.

title: Le roi malgré lui
factoid: Ravel claimed he would rather have written this comic opera than Wagner's Ring cycle, though the plot is notoriously confused.

title: Otello
factoid: The first of Verdi's late-period masterpieces was set to a libretto by Arrigo Boito.

title: Le roi d'Ys
factoid: A Breton folk tale with music heavily influenced by Wagner.

title: Cavalleria rusticana
factoid: A perennial favourite with audiences around the world, this one-acter is usually performed alongside Leoncavallo's Pagliacci.

title: Prince Igor
factoid: Borodin spent 17 years working on this opera off and on, yet never managed to finish it. Most famous for its "Polovtsian dances".

title: The Queen of Spades
factoid: In a letter to his brother and librettist the composer said that "the opera is a masterpiece".

title: L'amico Fritz
factoid: This work has been thought of as a late example of opera semiseria.

title: Iolanta
factoid: Tchaikovsky's last lyrical opera set to a libretto by his brother Modest.

title: La Wally
factoid: Usually considered Catalani's masterpiece.

title: Pagliacci
factoid: One of the most famous verismo operas, usually paired with Mascagni's Cavalleria rusticana.

title: Werther
factoid: Along with Manon, this is Massenet's most popular opera.

title: Falstaff
factoid: Verdi's final opera was set to another of Boito's libretti.

title: Hänsel und Gretel
factoid: The well-known fairy tale received a full Wagnerian operatic adaptation at Humperdinck's hands.

title: Manon Lescaut
factoid: The success of this work established Puccini's reputation as a composer of contemporary music of the first rank.

title: Thaïs (opera)
factoid: The opera that contains the famous Méditation interlude.

title: Andrea Chénier
factoid: Set to a libretto by Luigi Illica, this verismo drama is Giordano's most popular opera.

title: La bohème
factoid: Debussy is alleged to have said that no one had detailed Paris at that time better than had Puccini in La Boheme.

title: Königskinder
factoid: Originally a melodrama that blended song and spoken dialogue, the composer adapted the work into an opera proper in 1907.

title: Fedora
factoid: Giordano's second most popular opera.

title: Sadko
factoid: The Viking Trader's song from this opera has become extremely popular in Russia.

title: Cendrillon
factoid: An immediate success at the time of the premiere, the opera enjoyed 50 performances in 1899 alone.

title: The Devil and Kate
factoid: The lack of a love interest makes the plot of this work almost unique among Czech comic operas.

title: Louise
factoid: An attempt to provide a French equivalent for Italian verismo, Louise is set in a working-class district of Paris.

title: Tosca
factoid: Tosca is the most Wagnerian of Puccini's operas, with its frequent use of leitmotif.

title: Rusalka
factoid: Dvořák's most successful opera with international audiences, based on a folk tale about a water sprite.

title: Adriana Lecouvreur
factoid: Unique among Cilea's operas in that it has remained in the international repertory up to the present time.

title: Pelléas et Mélisande
factoid: Debussy's elusive Symbolist drama is one of the most significant operas of the 20th century.

title: Saul og David
factoid: This Biblical tragedy was the first of Nielsen's two operas.

title: Jenůfa
factoid: Janáček's first great success, a naturalistic depiction of Czech peasant life.

title: Madama Butterfly
factoid: The first performance of Puccini's now-popular opera was a disaster involving accusations of plagiarism.

title: Die lustige Witwe
factoid: One of the most famous Viennese operettas.

title: Salome
factoid: A scandalous success at its premiere, Strauss's "decadent" opera set to Oscar Wilde's play is still immensely popular with today's audiences.

title: Maskarade
factoid: Nielsen's high-spirited comedy looks back to the world of The Marriage of Figaro and has become a classic in the composer's native Denmark.

title: A Village Romeo and Juliet
factoid: A tragedy of unhappy love set in Switzerland; the most famous music is the interlude "The Walk to the Paradise Garden".

title: Ariane et Barbe-bleue
factoid: Dukas's only surviving opera, based like Debussy's Pelléas, on a Symbolist drama by Maeterlinck.

title: The Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh
factoid: A mystical retelling of an old national legend. Sometimes called the Russian Parsifal.

title: Destiny
factoid: An important transitional work in Janáček's career as the composer began to look beyond the traditional themes of Czech opera.

title: Elektra
factoid: This dark tragedy took Strauss's music to the borders of atonality. It was the composer's first setting of a libretto by his long-term collaborator Hugo von Hofmannsthal.

title: Il segreto di Susanna
factoid: A comic intermezzo. Susanna's secret is that she smokes.

title: The Golden Cockerel
factoid: Often considered Rimsky's greatest work, this satire on military incompetence got the composer into trouble with the censors after Russia's defeat in the Russo-Japanese War.

title: Don Quichotte
factoid: Massenet's last great success is a gentle comedy inspired by Cervantes's Don Quixote.

title: La fanciulla del West
factoid: Described by Puccini as his best work.

title: Der Rosenkavalier
factoid: Strauss and Hofmannsthal's most popular work, this comedy is set in 18th century Vienna.

title: L'heure espagnole
factoid: Ravel's first opera is a bedroom farce set in Spain.

title: Ariadne auf Naxos
factoid: A mixture of comedy and tragedy with an opera within an opera.

title: Der ferne Klang
factoid: The success of this work established Schreker's reputation as an opera composer.

title: La vida breve
factoid: A passionate Spanish drama influenced by verismo.

title: The Immortal Hour
factoid: Boughton's Celtic fairy tale opera enjoyed great popularity in Britain between the world wars.

title: The Nightingale
factoid: Stravinsky's style changed radically during the composition of this short opera, moving away from the influence of his teacher Rimsky-Korsakov towards the spiky modernism of the Rite of Spring.

title: Sāvitri
factoid: Holst's interest in Hinduism led him to set this episode from the Mahabharata.

title: Arlecchino
factoid: Busoni drew on the tradition of Italian commedia dell'arte for this one-act piece.

title: Eine florentinische Tragödie
factoid: Zemlinsky's "decadent" one-acter is based on a short play by Oscar Wilde.

title: La rondine
factoid: Not an initial success, Puccini heavily revised the opera twice.

title: Palestrina
factoid: A Wagnerian drama exploring the clash between innovation and tradition in music.

title: Bluebeard's Castle
factoid: Bartók's only opera, this intense psychological drama is one of his most important works.

title: Gianni Schicchi
factoid: One act in structure, Puccini's work is based on an extract from Dante's Inferno.

title: Il tabarro
factoid: The first of the operas that make up Il trittico – along with Gianni Schicchi and Suor Angelica

title: Suor Angelica
factoid: Described by the composer as his favourite among the three operas that comprise Il trittico.

title: Die Frau ohne Schatten
factoid: The third full collaboration between Strauss and the librettist Hofmannsthal gestated for six years before completion, and another two years passed before the first performance.

title: Die tote Stadt
factoid: Korngold's best known work for the stage.

title: The Excursions of Mr. Broucek
factoid: A comic fantasy set on the moon and in 15th century Bohemia.

title: Káťa Kabanová
factoid: The first of the great operas of Janáček's late maturity, based on an Ostrovsky play about religious fanaticism and forbidden love in provincial Russia.

title: The Love for Three Oranges
factoid: A comic opera based on a fairy tale by Carlo Gozzi.

title: Der Zwerg
factoid: Another short Zemlinsky opera inspired by a work by Oscar Wilde. The composer personally identified with the dwarf of the title.

title: Erwartung
factoid: An intense atonal monodrama.

title: Hugh the Drover
factoid: A ballad opera, much of which is based on folksongs.

title: Intermezzo
factoid: A light operetta-style work based on an incident from the composer's own marriage.

title: The Cunning Little Vixen
factoid: One of the composer's most popular works, the story is based on a cartoon strip about animals in the Czech countryside.

title: Doktor Faust
factoid: Busoni intended this opera to be the climax of his career, but it was left unfinished at his death.

title: L'enfant et les sortilèges
factoid: Conceived as an opera-ballet, "birds, beasts, insects, even inanimate objects, teach humanity to the child".

title: Wozzeck
factoid: One of the key operas of the 20th century. Based on a strikingly unheroic plot, Berg's work blends atonal techniques with more traditional ones.

title: Cardillac
factoid: An opera in Hindemith's neo-classical style about a psychopathic jeweller.

title: Háry János
factoid: Kodálys singspiel incorporated many Hungarian folksongs and dances.

title: King Roger
factoid: One of the most important Polish operas, this piece is full of Oriental harmonies.

title: The Makropulos Affair
factoid: The first performance of The Makropulos Affair was the last that Janáček survived to see among his operas.

title: Turandot
factoid: Puccini's last opera was left unfinished at his death.

title: Oedipus Rex
factoid: Set to a Latin libretto by Jean Cocteau, this highly stylised piece fuses opera and oratorio.

title: Jonny spielt auf
factoid: A "jazz opera" which enjoyed tremendous success in its day.

title: The Threepenny Opera
factoid: A modern adaptation of Gay and Pepusch's The Beggar's Opera.

title: The Nose
factoid: Gogol's strange short story provided the plot for this grotesque satire.

title: Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny
factoid: The composition of this opera was problematic, due to tension between the composer and his librettist, Bertolt Brecht.

title: From the House of the Dead
factoid: Janáček's last opera inspired by Dostoevsky's account of life in a Russian prison camp.

title: Moses und Aron
factoid: Left unfinished at his death, Schoenberg's opera frequently employs serialist techniques.

title: Arabella
factoid: This opera was the last that Strauss set to a libretto by Hugo von Hofmannsthal.

title: Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District
factoid: An attack on the music and subject matter of the opera in the Soviet Union's government journal Pravda meant that this work was Shostakovich's last opera.

title: Die schweigsame Frau
factoid: A comic opera based on a play by Ben Jonson.

title: Porgy and Bess
factoid: Initially a financial failure, a 1941 production that replaced the work's recitatives with spoken dialogue was a success.

title: Lulu
factoid: Berg's second opera was unfinished at his death, but a completion by Friedrich Cerha was successfully performed in 1979.

title: Riders to the Sea
factoid: Often rated as Vaughan Williams's finest opera, this short, fatalistic tragedy is set on the Aran Isles in the west of Ireland.

title: Daphne
factoid: A mythological opera with lyrical, pastoral music.

title: Julietta
factoid: This dreamlike work set in a town where people have lost their memory is "Martinu's operatic masterpiece".

title: Mathis der Maler
factoid: Hindemith's most highly regarded opera is a parable about an artist surviving in a time of crisis, reflecting the composer's own experience under the Nazis.

title: Paul Bunyan
factoid: Britten's first venture into opera was a light piece about an American folk hero with a libretto by W. H. Auden.

title: Capriccio
factoid: Strauss's final opera is a conversation piece about the genre itself.

title: Der Kaiser von Atlantis
factoid: Written in the Nazi concentration camp Theresienstadt and not performed until 1975. The composer and his librettist were murdered in Auschwitz concentration camp.

title: Peter Grimes
factoid: A landmark in the history of British opera, this work marked Britten's arrival on the international music scene.

title: War and Peace
factoid: Prokofiev returned to the tradition of Russian historical opera for this epic work based on Leo Tolstoy's novel.

title: Betrothal in a Monastery
factoid: A romantic comedy with music drawing on the opera buffa style of Rossini.

title: The Medium
factoid: Considered by many to be Menotti's finest work.

title: The Rape of Lucretia
factoid: Britten's first chamber opera.

title: Albert Herring
factoid: Britten's comic opera is heavily based upon use of the ensemble.

title: Dantons Tod
factoid: Einem's opera is a compressed setting of Georg Büchner's play about the "Reign of Terror" during the French Revolution.

title: Les mamelles de Tirésias
factoid: Poulenc's first opera is a short surrealist comedy based on the play by Guillaume Apollinaire.

title: The Telephone, or L'Amour à trois
factoid: An opera buffa just 22 minutes in length.

title: Il prigioniero
factoid: Much of the music for this opera is based on three 12-note tone rows, which represent the themes of prayer, hope and freedom that dominate the opera.

title: The Consul
factoid: This opera contains some of Menotti's most dissonant music.

title: Amahl and the Night Visitors
factoid: This Christmas story was the first opera specifically written for television.

title: Billy Budd
factoid: The plot for Britten's large-scale opera was based on a story by Herman Melville.

title: The Pilgrim's Progress
factoid: Set to his own libretto, Vaughan Williams's work was inspired by John Bunyan's famous allegory of the same name.

title: The Rake's Progress
factoid: Stravinsky's most important operatic work looks back to Mozart musically and has a libretto by W. H. Auden inspired by the engravings of William Hogarth.

title: Boulevard Solitude
factoid: Henze's first full-length opera is an updating of the story of Manon Lescaut, also the source for important operas by Massenet and Puccini.

title: Gloriana
factoid: Composed for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, this opera looks back to the relationship between her namesake Elizabeth I and the Earl of Essex.

title: The Fiery Angel
factoid: Prokofiev never saw what is often regarded as his most avant-garde composition performed on the operatic stage.

title: The Turn of the Screw
factoid: A chamber opera based on the ghost story by Henry James. It is remarkable for its tightly laid out key scheme and active orchestral role.

title: Troilus and Cressida
factoid: Walton's opera about the Trojan War was initially a failure.

title: The Midsummer Marriage
factoid: Tippett's first full-scale opera was set to his own libretto.

title: Candide
factoid: Operetta, based on Voltaire. The soprano aria "Glitter and Be Gay" is a parody of Romantic-era jewel songs.

title: Dialogues des Carmélites
factoid: Poulenc's major opera is set in a convent during the French Revolution.

title: Vanessa
factoid: Vanessa won its composer a Pulitzer Prize in 1958.

title: La voix humaine
factoid: A short opera with a single character: a despairing woman on the telephone to her lover.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
factoid: Set to a libretto adapted from the Shakespeare play by himself and his partner Peter Pears, Britten's work is rare in operatic history in that it features a countertenor in the male lead role.

title: Elegy for Young Lovers
factoid: Henze asked his librettists, W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman, for a scenario that would inspire him to compose "tender, beautiful noises".

title: King Priam
factoid: Tippett's second opera, set to another of his own "recondite" libretti, was inspired by Homer's Iliad.

title: Curlew River
factoid: A modern liturgical "church opera" intended for performance in an ecclesiastical setting.

title: Der junge Lord
factoid: The last composition produced during Henze's dwelling in Italy is considered to be the most Italianate of his dramatic works.

title: Die Soldaten
factoid: The first version of the opera was rejected by Cologne Opera as impossible for them to stage: Zimmermann was required to reduce the orchestral forces required and to cut some of the technical demands previously required.

title: Antony and Cleopatra
factoid: The first version of the opera was set to a libretto consisting entirely of the words of Shakespeare and deemed a failure. Later it was revised by Gian Carlo Menotti and became a success.

title: The Bassarids
factoid: Henze's opera is set to a libretto by Auden and Kallman, who required that the composer listen to Götterdämmerung before starting to compose the music.

title: The Bear
factoid: The libretto for Walton's extravaganza was based on Chekov.

title: Punch and Judy
factoid: Birtwistle's first opera was commissioned by the English Opera Group.

title: The Prodigal Son
factoid: The third of Britten's parables for church performance.

title: The Devils of Loudun
factoid: Penderecki's first opera is also his most popular.

title: The Knot Garden
factoid: Tippett created his own modern scenario for the libretto of this work, his third opera.

title: Owen Wingrave
factoid: Britten's anti-war opera was written especially for BBC television.

title: Taverner
factoid: Davies was one of the most significant figures to emerge in British music the 1960s. This opera is based on a legend about the 16th-century composer John Taverner.

title: Death in Venice
factoid: Britten's last opera was first performed three years before his death.

title: Einstein on the Beach
factoid: Philip Glass' first opera conceived together with director Robert Wilson introduced minimalist composition and avantgarde performance to the world of opera and remains one of the best known operas of the twentieth century.

title: Le Grand Macabre
factoid: First performed at Stockholm in 1978, Ligeti heavily revised the opera in 1996.

title: Lear
factoid: An Expressionist opera based on Shakespeare's tragedy. The title role was specifically written for the famous baritone Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau.

title: The Lighthouse
factoid: Davies's second chamber opera was set to his own libretto.

title: Saint François d'Assise
factoid: 120 orchestral players are required for this opera, as well as a sizable chorus.

title: Un re in ascolto
factoid: This opera was set to a libretto assembled by the composer from three different texts by three different authors: Friedrich Einsiedel, W. H. Auden and Friedrich Wilhelm Gotter.

title: Akhnaten
factoid: Unlike his first opera Einstein on the Beach, the writing and style are more conventional and lyrical and much of the music of Akhnaten is some of the most dissonant that Glass has composed.

title: The Mask of Orpheus
factoid: Birtwistle's most ambitious opera examines the myth of Orpheus from several different angles.

title: A Night at the Chinese Opera
factoid: This piece is based on a Chinese play of the Yuan dynasty, The Orphan of Zhao.

title: Nixon in China
factoid: Musically minimalist in style, this opera recounts Richard Nixon's 1972 meeting with Mao Zedong.

title: Gawain
factoid: Birtwistle's opera is based on the medieval English poem Sir Gawain and the Green Knight.

title: A Streetcar Named Desire
factoid: The opera is based on the play by Tennessee Williams.

title: Dafne
factoid: The first opera, performed in Florence (music now lost).

title: Euridice
factoid: The earliest opera whose music survives.

title: La liberazione di Ruggiero
factoid: First opera by a woman.

title: Dafne
factoid: First German opera. Music now lost.

title: La púrpura de la rosa
factoid: First Spanish opera. Music now lost.

title: Pomone
factoid: Often regarded as the first French opera.

title: Venus and Adonis
factoid: Often considered the first opera in English.

title: La púrpura de la rosa
composer: Tomás de Torrejón y Velasco, born in Spain 1644
factoid: Earliest known opera composed in the Americas.

title: Partenope
factoid: The first opera written by an American-born composer and the earliest known full opera produced in North America.

title: Tsefal i Prokris
factoid: First Russian opera.
